ngiemboon: À něŋ shúm tsɛ̀ɛ pìʼi ńcʉŋe nzèm kwáŋ we.
en: He put the things in the cart and tied it behind his bike.
them (as a second pronoun in a complex pronoun)

ngiemboon: Mèŋ n gɔɔn ngie pɔ́ lâ pɔ̌ e tó.
en: I said they are coming with them.
their (third person plural possessive adjective modifying any class noun after preposition or a movement verb)
theirs (3rd person plural possessive pronoun referring back to class 2 nouns)
theirs (3rd person plural possessive adjective modifying class 4 and 6 nouns)
theirs (3rd person plural emphatic possessive adjective modifying class 4 and 6 nouns)

ngiemboon: Ndyé ne ńkẅɛɛ na káb lê pɔ́g páʼ fʉ̀ʼ gie kẅɛɛ tsɛ̀ɛ tàŋ matûa la.
en: The smoke comes out of the pipe as if it were coming out of the car exhaust.
yours and mine (first and second person singular pronoun referring back to class 2 nouns)
your and my (first and second person singular adjective modifying class 2 nouns)
your and my (first and second person emphatic singular adjective modifying class 2 nouns)
Here are the pigs. Go stop yours and mine.

ngiemboon: À kabá pɔ̀gɔ pîɛ, à ge gÿo jÿó, à lẅe.
en: He picked an immature avocado, it will be bitter when he eats it.
us two (first and second person singular inclusive subject pronoun)
Come, you and I will join him.
these here (close demonstrative pronoun referring to class 2 nouns)
these ... here (close demonstrative adjective modifying class 2 nouns)

ngiemboon: N jǔʼ ngie ɔ̀ táŋa menɔ̀ɔn
en: I learned that you sell animals

ngiemboon: N jǔʼ ngie ɔ̀ táŋa menɔ̀ɔn

en: I learned that you sell animals
Give these people something to eat.
mine (first person singular possessive pronoun referring back to class 2 nouns)
my (first person singular possessive adjective modifying class 2 nouns)
my (first person singular emphatic possessive adjective modifying class 2 nouns)
